question: An aircraft’s mass is a result of:
explanation: Mass is the measure of the amount of matter in an object, independent of gravity. Weight, on the other hand, is the force exerted on mass due to gravity.
subject: Technical

question: The unit of mass is the:
explanation:
The kilogram (kg) is the SI unit of mass. The other options represent different physical quantities:

  • Joule (J) → Unit of energy
  • Watt (W) → Unit of power
  • Newton (N) → Unit of force.
subject: Technical

question: The definition of a force is:

choices.choice: That which causes a reaction to take place.
The result of an applied input

explanation: Force is defined as an interaction that causes an object to accelerate, change direction, or deform. It can be a push or a pull acting on an object.
subject: Technical

question: The unit of force is the
explanation:
The Newton (N) is the SI unit of force. It is defined as the force required to accelerate a 1 kg mass by 1 m/s² (N = kg·m/s²).

The other options represent different physical quantities:

  • Mass-kilogram (kg) → Unit of mass
  • Newton-metre (N·m) → Unit of torque
  • Joule (J) → Unit of energy.
subject: Technical

question: The unit of weight is the
explanation:
Weight is a force, calculated as mass × gravitational acceleration (W = mg), and its SI unit is the Newton (N).

The other options represent different physical quantities:

  • Kilogram (kg) → Unit of mass
  • Watt (W) → Unit of power
  • Kilowatt (kW) → Unit of power (1 kW = 1000 W)
subject: Technical

question: Weight is the result of:

choices.choice: The force on mass due to gravity
The action of a falling mass
How much matter the object contains
The rate of mass per unit area

explanation:
Weight is the force exerted on an object due to gravity. It is calculated as:

W=mg

where W is weight (in Newtons), m is mass (in kg), and g is gravitational acceleration (~9.81 m/s² on Earth).
subject: Technical

question: About which point does an aircraft rotate:
explanation:
Centre of Gravity (CG)

  • The Centre of Gravity (CG) is the theoretical point where the entire weight of an aircraft is considered to act.
  • It is the balance point of the aircraft, meaning if suspended at the CG, the aircraft would remain level.
  • The CG affects stability, control, and performance, and must remain within approved limits for safe operation.
subject: Technical

question: If a force is applied to a mass and the mass does not move:

choices.choice: Work is done even through there is no movement of the mass
Work is done only if the mass moves a long way
Power is exerted, but no work is done

explanation:
• Work is done when a force moves a body in the direction of the force.

  • The amount of work done is given by:                          Work=Force × Distance

  • If no movement occurs despite the force being applied, no work is done.
subject: Technical

question: The unit of work is called the:
explanation:
Work is measured in Joules (J), where:                          1 Joule=1 Newton×1 metre(N⋅m)

The other units represent different physical quantities:

  • Pascal (Pa) → Unit of pressure
  • Watt (W) → Unit of power
  • Kilogram (kg) → Unit of mass
subject: Technical

question: The unit of power is called the:
explanation:
Power is the rate of doing work and is measured in Watts (W), where:

1 Watt=1 Joule per second(J/s)

Other units:

  • Joule (J) → Unit of work/energy
  • Newton-metre (N·m) → Unit of torque
  • Metre per second (m/s) → Unit of velocity
subject: Technical

question: If a force of 20 Newton’s moves a mass 5 metres: 1-The work done is 100Nm 2-The work done is 100 Joules 3-The work done is 4 Joules 4-The work done is 0.25 Joules The correct statements are:
explanation:
1 and 2

Work done is calculated as:

Work=Force×Distance                                                      =20N×5m=100J

Since 1 Nm = 1 Joule, both 100 Nm and 100 Joules are correct.
subject: Technical

question: If a force of 50 Newton’s is applied to a 10 kg mass and the mass moves 10 metres and a force of 50 Newton’s is applied to a 100kg mass which moves 10 metres:

choices.choice: The work done is the same in both cases
Less work is done to the 10 kg mass
More work is done to the 10 kg mass
More work is done to the 100 kg mass

explanation:
Work done is calculated as:

Work=Force×Distance

For both cases:

50N×10m=500J

Since the force and distance are the same, the work done is the same, regardless of mass.
subject: Technical

question: The definition of power is:

choices.choice: The rate of movement per second

explanation:
Power is defined as the rate at which work is done, given by:

Power=WorkTime​

Its unit is the Watt (W), where 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second (J/s).
subject: Technical

question: If a force of 500 Newton’s moves a mass 1000 metres in 2 mins, the power used is:
explanation:
Power is the rate of doing work.

  • power = work / time
  • work = force × distance = 500N × 1000m = 500,000J
  • time = 2 mins = 120s
  • power = 500,000J / 120s = 4166.67W ≈ 4167W
subject: Technical

question: Kinetic energy is:

choices.choice: The energy a mass possesses due to its position in space
The energy a mass possesses when a force has been applied
The energy a mass possesses due to the force of gravity
The energy a mass possesses because of its motion

explanation:
Kinetic energy (KE) is the energy possessed by a mass because of its motion.

  • KE = ½ × mass × velocity²
  • A moving mass can do work when coming to rest.
  • Unit: joule (J)
  • The faster or heavier an object, the more kinetic energy it has.
subject: Technical

question: The unit of kinetic energy is the:
explanation:
• kinetic energy (KE) = ½ × mass × velocity²
  • unit: joule (J) (same as work and energy)
subject: Technical

question: When considering kinetic energy: 1-a moving mass can apply a force by being brought to rest. 2-kinetic energy is the energy possessed by a body because of its motion. 3-if a body’s kinetic energy is increased , a force must have been applied. 4- kinetic energy = ½ m V² joules. The combination of correct statement is:
explanation:
1, 2, 3, and 4

All statements are correct:

  • 1 → A moving mass can apply a force when coming to rest.
  • 2 → Kinetic energy is the energy possessed due to motion.
  • 3 → Increasing kinetic energy requires a force.
  • 4 → KE = ½ × mass × velocity² (Joules).
subject: Technical

question: The property of inertia is said to be:

choices.choice: The energy possessed by a body because of its motion
The opposition which a body offers to a change in motion
That every action has an equal and opposite reaction
The quantity of motion possessed by a body

explanation:
• Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its motion.
  • It is based on Newton’s First Law of Motion (law of inertia).
  • More mass = more inertia (harder to change motion).
subject: Technical

question: Considering Newton’s first law of motion: 1-a body is said to have energy if it has the ability to do work. 2-The amount of energy a body possesses is measured by the amount of work it can do. 3-a body will tend to remain at rest, or in uniform motion in a straight line, unless acted upon by an external force. 4-to move a stationary object or to make a moving object changes its direction, a force must be applied. The combination with the correct statements is:
explanation:
Newton’s First Law of Motion states:

“A body remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.”

  • Statement 1: “A body is said to have energy if it has the ability to do work.”

    • This is correct but relates to energy, not Newton’s First Law.

  • Statement 2: “The amount of energy a body possesses is measured by the amount of work it can do.”

    • Also correct, but describes work and energy, not Newton’s First Law.

  • Statement 3: “A body will tend to remain at rest, or in uniform motion in a straight line, unless acted upon by an external force.”

    • This directly describes Newton’s First Law.

  • Statement 4: “To move a stationary object or to make a moving object change its direction, a force must be applied.”

    • This aligns with Newton’s First Law, as an external force is required to change motion.
subject: Technical

question: Considering Newton’s second law of motion: 1- every action has an equal and opposite reaction. 2-If the same force is applied, the larger the mass the slower the acceleration. 3-If two forces are applied to the same mass, the bigger the force the greater the acceleration. 4-the acceleration of a body from a state of rest, or uniform motion in a straight line, is proportional to the applied force and inversely proportional to the mass. The combination of true statements is:
explanation:
Newton’s Second Law states:

“The acceleration of a body is directly proportional to the applied force and inversely proportional to its mass.” (F = ma)

  • Statement 1: “Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.”

    • This describes Newton’s Third Law, not the Second Law.

  • Statement 2: “If the same force is applied, the larger the mass, the slower the acceleration.”

    • From F = ma, when mass increases, acceleration decreases.

  • Statement 3: “If two forces are applied to the same mass, the bigger the force, the greater the acceleration.”

    • From F = ma, a larger force results in greater acceleration.

  • Statement 4: “The acceleration of a body from a state of rest, or uniform motion in a straight line, is proportional to the applied force and inversely proportional to the mass.”

    • This is the direct definition of Newton’s Second Law.

Thus, the correct combination is Option C: 2, 3, and 4.
subject: Technical

question: Newton’s third law of motion states:

choices.choice: The energy possessed by a mass is inversely proportional to its velocity
Every force has an equal and opposite inertia
For every force there is an action.
Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

explanation:
Newton’s Third Law states:

“For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.”

This means that if an object exerts a force on another object, the second object exerts an equal force in the opposite direction.

Examples:

  • A rocket pushes exhaust gases downward, and the gases push the rocket upward.
  • A bird flaps its wings downward, and the air pushes it upward.
subject: Technical

question: The definition of velocity is the:

choices.choice: The quantity of motion possessed by a body
The acceleration of a body in direct proportion to its mass

explanation:
Velocity is defined as the rate of change of displacement with respect to time.

Formula:
velocity (v) = displacement (s) / time (t)

Key points:

  • Velocity includes both magnitude and direction (it is a vector).
  • It differs from speed, which only considers magnitude.
  • A body moving in a straight line at constant speed has a constant velocity.
subject: Technical

question: When considering acceleration: 1-acceleration is the rate of change of velocity 2-the units of acceleration are metres per second 3-the units of acceleration are kilogram-metres per second. 4-the units of acceleration are seconds per metre per metre. The combination of correct statements is:
explanation:
1 only

Explanation:

  1. ✅ Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. (Correct)

    • Definition: Acceleration measures how quickly velocity changes over time.
    • Formula: a = (v – u) / t

  2. ❌ The units of acceleration are metres per second. (Incorrect)

    • The correct unit is metres per second squared (m/s²), not just metres per second (m/s).

  3. ❌ The units of acceleration are kilogram-metres per second. (Incorrect)

    • kg·m/s is the unit of momentum, not acceleration.

  4. ❌ The units of acceleration are seconds per metre per metre. (Incorrect)

    • This does not correctly represent acceleration.
subject: Technical

question: The definition of momentum is:

choices.choice: The quantity of mass possessed by a body.
The quantity of inertia possessed by a body.
The quantity of motion possessed by a body.
The opposition which a body offers to a change in velocity

explanation:
Momentum

  • Unit: kg·m/s (Mass × Velocity)
  • Definition: The quantity of motion possessed by a body.
  • Concept: A body in motion tends to stay in motion unless acted upon by an external force (Newton’s First Law).
  • Formula: momentum (p) = mass (m) × velocity (v)
  • Momentum represents the tendency of a body to continue moving after being set in motion.
subject: Technical

question: A force of 24 Newton’s moves a 10 kg mass 60 metres in 1 minute, the power used is? 1-24 Watts 2-240 Watts. 3-Force times distance moved in one second. 4-Force times the distance the mass is moved in one second. Which of the preceding statements are correct
explanation:
power = work done ÷ time

work done = force × distance
 = 24n × 60m = 1440 joules

power = 1440 ÷ 60 = 24 watts

  • ✅ 24 watts (correct) – this is the calculated power.
  • ❌ 240 watts (incorrect) – the correct power is 24 w, not 240 w.
  • ✅ force × distance moved in one second (correct) – this is the definition of power.
  • ✅ force × distance the mass is moved in one second (correct) – same as statement 3.
subject: Technical

question: When considering momentum: 1- Momentum is the quantity of motion possessed by a body. 2-Momentum is the tendency of a body to continue in motion after being placed in motion. 3-A mass of 2000 kg moving at 55 m/s has 110000 kg-m/s of momentum. 4-A large mass moving at 50 m/s will have less momentum than a small mass moving at 50 m/s. The correct combination of statement is:
explanation:
1, 2, and 3.

Explanation:

  1. Momentum is the quantity of motion possessed by a body – Correct (Momentum = mass × velocity).
  2. Momentum is the tendency of a body to continue in motion – Correct (This describes inertia in motion).
  3. A mass of 2000 kg moving at 55 m/s has 110,000 kg·m/s of momentum – Correct (Momentum = 2000 × 55 = 110,000 kg·m/s).
  4. A large mass moving at 50 m/s will have less momentum than a small mass moving at 50 m/s – Incorrect (A larger mass will have more momentum at the same velocity).
subject: Technical
